com.versant.fund
Class FundSession

java.lang.Object
  com.versant.fund.Constants
      com.versant.fund.MSessionVar
          com.versant.fund.Capi
              com.versant.fund.SynchronizedCapi
                  com.versant.fund.MSession
                      com.versant.fund.FundSession
All Implemented Interfaces:
ClassBuilder, Session, SessionWithDatabase
Direct Known Subclasses:
TransSession
public class FundSession
extends MSession
implements Session

A FundSession encapsulates a database session which can be accessed by multiple threads, supporting a multi-thread multi-session application structure.

Usage: 

   Capability cap = new NewSessionCapability ();

   Properties prop = new Properties ();

   prop.put ("database", "mydb");

   prop.put ("sessionName", "mySession1");

   FundSession s = new FundSession (prop, cap);

Constructor Detail

FundSession

public FundSession(java.util.Properties prop,
                   Capability cap)
Constructs a FundSession with the given Capability and begins a session which allows multiple sessions and multiple threads in a session.

The prop parameter is an instance of java.util.Properties that contains key-value pairs to specify a list of properties of a session. Following are valid keys, their values, and their meanings.

Key: "database"

  • a string of max length of 31 characters
  • The name of a personal or group database to start the session on.

Key: "sessionName"

  • a string of max length of 31 characters.
  • The name of the database session. If you start multiple, concurrent sessions, each session name must be unique within the same process.
Key: "longTransaction"

  • a string of max length of 30 characters less the length of your user name.
  • The name of a long transaction for the session.
Key: "options"

  • "0"
      Start a "standard session" that uses the standard VERSANT session, transaction, and locking models. This is the default
  • Constants.OPT_LK + ""
      Start an "optimistic locking session" that suppresses object swapping, prevents automatic lock upgrades, and provides automatic collision notification.
  • Constants.READ_ACCESS + ""
      Start a session with read connection mode that allows you to view but not change data. If you make a connection with a read mode access and then change an object, you will get the error NET_RW_ACCESS_REQUIRED when you try to commit your transaction (permissions are checked by the database server process).
  • Constants.WRITE_ACCESS + ""
      Start a session with write connection mode that allows you to edit data. This access mode is not currently supported, but may be supported in future releases. At present, this mode is the same as READ_ACCESS|WRITE_ACCESS.
  • (Constants.READ_ACCESS | Constants.WRITE_ACCESS) + ""
      Start a session with connection mode that allows you to view and edit data in your session database.
  • Constants.DONT_JOIN + ""
      Do not attach thread to the new session. The default is to attach the thread to the new session.
Key: "lockmode"

  • Constants.NOLOCK + ""
      • Use no lock as the default lock mode for this session.
  • Constants.WLOCK + ""
      • Use write lock as the default lock mode for this session.
  • Constants.ULOCK + ""
      Use update lock as the default lock mode for this session.
  • Constants.RLOCK + ""
      • Use read lock as the default lock mode for this session.
Key: "userName"

  • a string of max length of 31 characters
  • The name of the user who is authorized to connect to the Database
Key: "userPassword"

  • a string of max length of 256 characters
  • The password associated with the name of an authorized user.
To create "secure" sessions with a VERSANT database, you can create an instance of Capability and use the constructor that accepts a Capability instance as a parameter. The public class NewSessionCapability implements the Capability interface and its constructor enforces that only one instance can be created per Java class loader.

Parameters:
prop - The instance of java.util.Properties that contains session options.
cap - The VERSANT Capability instance required to create a "secure" VERSANT/Java Session.

FundSession

public FundSession(java.util.Properties prop)
Constructs a FundSession and begins a session which allows multiple sessions and multiple threads in a session.

See the previous constructor form for an explanation of the prop parameter.

This is an "insecure" mode of creating a VERSANT session. In addition, all other Session constructors cannot use a Capability parameter once this constructor has been used.

This constructor will throw an exception if a Capability instance has been explicitly created elsewhere using this class loader.

Parameters:
prop - The instance of java.util.Properties that contains session options.

FundSession

public FundSession(java.lang.String dbName)
Constructs a FundSession on the named database.

The current thread attaches itself to the new session implicitly.

The constructor does not require a Capability, and will throw an exception if a Capability instance has been explicitly created elsewhere.

Parameters:
dbName - The name of the database on which to create this session.

FundSession

public FundSession(java.lang.String dbName,
                   java.lang.String sessionName)
Constructs a FundSession with the given session name on the named database.

The current thread attaches itself to the new session implicitly.

The session name must be unique across the process.

The constructor does not require a Capability, and will throw an exception if a Capability instance has been explicitly created elsewhere.

Parameters:
sessionName - The name of the session to create.
dbName - The name of the database on which to create this session.
Method Detail

setSession

public void setSession()
Associates the current thread with this session.

If the current thread is currently associated with a session, it is automatically disassociated from its current session first.

Before accessing objects in another session, a thread must first attach itself to that session, and the thread to attach itself to that session can use this method.

Throws:
VException - EVJ_BAD_SESSION if session not begun, or session already ended.
See Also:
FundSession.leaveSession()

leaveSession

public void leaveSession()
Disassociates thread from this session.

Before accessing objects in another session, a thread must first detach itself from the session it currently is in and then attach itself to the other session. This method can be used to detach the thread from the session.

endSession

public void endSession(int option)
Ends this session using the given option, performs a short commit, terminates the current database session and closes associated communication channels to the database server.

endSession always commits the changes made within the context of the current transaction to the database. If this is undesirable then the changes made in the current transaction have to be rolled back before calling endSession.

The option parameter can include the following values:

  • Constants.ENDSESSION_DETACH Detach the current thread from this session if the session is in use by another thread.
  • Constants.ENDSESSION_FORCE Forcefully end the session even if the session is in use by another thread. The current thread does not need to be attached to the session either.

By default, to end a session, the current thread must be the only thread that's attached to the session; otherwise, an exception is thrown. Specifying one of the previous two options can change the default behavior.

Overrides:
endSession in class MSession
Parameters:
option - An option with which to end this session.
Throws:
VException.EVJ_CANNOT_END_SESSION_INUSE - If the session is still in use and the option ENDSESSION_FORCE is not used.

VException.EVJ_CANNOT_END_UNATTACHED_SESSION - If the session is not attached to this thread.

See Also:
FundSession.endSession(), MSession.endSession(String), MSession.endSession(String, int)

endSession

public void endSession()
Ends this session, performs a short commit, terminates the current database session and closes associated communication channels to the database server.

endSession always commits the changes made within the context of the current transaction to the database. If this is undesirable then the changes made in the current transaction have to be rolled back before calling endSession.

To end a session, the current thread must be the only thread that is attached to the session.

Overrides:
endSession in class MSession
Throws:
VException.EVJ_CANNOT_END_SESSION_INUSE - If the session is still in use.

VException.EVJ_CANNOT_END_UNATTACHED_SESSION - If the session is not attached to this thread.

See Also:
FundSession.endSession(int), MSession.endSession(String), MSession.endSession(String, int)

getThreadOptions

public int getThreadOptions()
Returns the thread options of the current thread.

See Also:
FundSession.setThreadOptions(int)

setThreadOptions

public void setThreadOptions(int option)
Sets the thread options of the current thread to the specified option.

The only valid thread option to set is Constants.DROP_RLOCK. If DROP_RLOCK is set, RLOCK or IRLOCK are dropped when instance objects are retrieved from the database.

This option has no impact on the intention read locks set on the class objects corresponding to the instance objects received.

Read locks are held on instance objects during the duration of the read operation (which protects you from seeing uncommitted objects) and then dropped when the read operation is finished.

If you want to always drop read locks after fetching objects, this option reduces network calls because it causes locks to be dropped by the database server process. By comparison, dropping locks with a downgrade lock method requires a separate network message from the application process to the server process.

This option may be used in a standard session or an optimistic locking session.

The default is to not drop read locks when objects are fetched.

The lock downgrading action for this option is different from that of an explicit downgrade lock method call. For a read operation, if this option is on, the backend simply backs out the read lock introduced by your current operation. This means that after the operation, the lockmode of the object will be the same as that before the operation. For example, if there has been a read lock on the object before the read operation, with this option on, the read lock will not be released after the operation. This option does not introduce any new lock to the object.

Parameters:
option - the Thread option to set

See Also:
Constants, FundSession.getThreadOptions(), FundSession.unsetThreadOptions(int)

unsetThreadOptions

public void unsetThreadOptions(int option)
Resets the specified thread options of the current thread.

The only valid option is Constants.DROP_RLOCK. If DROP_RLOCK is set, RLOCK or IRLOCK are dropped when instance objects are retrieved from the database.

This option has no impact on the intention read locks set on the class objects corresponding to the instance objects received.

Parameters:
option - the Thread option to unset.
See Also:
Constants, FundSession.getThreadOptions(), FundSession.setThreadOptions(int)

setDefaultSession

public void setDefaultSession()
Sets this session to be the default session of this process.

If a thread has not attached to any session (either by instantiating a session object or invoking setSession()), when the thread tries to invoke any JVI methods that requires the thread to be in a database session, this thread will be automatically associated with the default session.

See Also:
FundSession.setSession(), (string)

newLogicalDatabase

public void newLogicalDatabase(java.lang.String logical_dbname)
The name of the logical database to create.

Method used for manipulating a set of databases ( collectively termed as logical database ) used in parallelizing queries. If a logical database has been established, queries will be parallelized by default by the VERSANT Client. Parallelization is done by spawning a thread to query each database. Once all threads are done, the results from all databases are aggregated and returned to the caller. The default can be changed by passing the appropriate option to the select method.

  • The SELECT_NO_LOGICAL_DB option turns off use of the logical database setting.
  • The SELECT_SERIAL option causes the databases in the logical database to be queried serially without spawning any threads.

See Also:
FundSession.addToLogicalDatabase(String, String), FundSession.deleteLogicalDatabase(String), FundSession.removeFromLogicalDatabase(String, String)

deleteLogicalDatabase

public void deleteLogicalDatabase(java.lang.String logical_dbname)
Deletes a logical database.

Deleting a logical database only deletes the abstract logical database; it does not delete the underlying physical databases.

Parameters:
logical_dbname - The name of the logical database to delete.
See Also:
FundSession.newLogicalDatabase(java.lang.String)

addToLogicalDatabase

                                 java.lang.String dbname)
Adds a VERSANT database to a logical database.

After calling addToLogicalDatabase(), the given VERSANT database will be queried in parallel when the logical database is specified in a query.

logical_dbname - The name of the logical database.
dbname - The name of the VERSANT database to add to the logical database.
See Also:

removeFromLogicalDatabase

public void removeFromLogicalDatabase(java.lang.String logical_dbname,
                                      java.lang.String dbname)
Removes a VERSANT database from a logical database.

After calling removeFromLogicalDatabase(), the given VERSANT database will no longer be included in queries that are performed on the logical database.

Parameters:
logical_dbname - The name of the logical database.
dbname - The name of the VERSANT database to remove from the logical database.
See Also:
FundSession.newLogicalDatabase(String)

setReplicaReporting

public void setReplicaReporting(java.lang.String dbname)
Enable error reporting for the current session if the database specified by dbname goes down. This function is used in synchronous replication environment since you will normally not be notified if a database in the replication pair goes down (the application automatically switches to use the other database in the replication pair).

Error reporting is off by default when a session is started. To use error reporting, call this function and then call switchReplicaReporting(true), switchReplicaReportingWithCommit(true) or switchReplicaReportingWithoutCommit(true). This will cause an error to be reported during commit for every transaction until switchReplicaReporting(false), switchReplicaReportingWithCommit(false) or switchReplicaReportingWithoutCommit(false) is called.

Parameters:
dbname - The name of the VERSANT database for which error reporting is to be turned on.

setPreferredDb

public void setPreferredDb(java.lang.String dbName)
Sets the database specified by dbName as preferred database for read operations for the duration of the current session.

This function is useful in a synchronous replication environment if it is faster to read from the secondary database than from the primary database, say, the primary database is remote and the secondary database is local.

When using synchronous database replication and perform a query, locate an object, or use the group read method, objects are read from the first database listed in the replica file (the "primary" database.) To alter this behavior, use this function to set a preferred read database.

After you have called this function, VERSANT will first try to read objects from the preferred database. If the preferred database is down, VERSANT will then try to read from the primary database.

To reduce the possibility of a deadlock with another user, after this function if you set a lock when you read an object, the lock will still be set first in the primary database and then in the secondary database.

If you are performing database replication for numerous sets of database pairs, you can call this function once for each replica pair. After calling this function, to restore the default behavior, you must call unsetPreferredDb(). If you call setPreferredDb() twice on a database in a particular database pair, the second call will be ignored.

Parameters:
dbName - the name of the VERSANT database which we preferred for the read operations.

unsetPreferredDb

public void unsetPreferredDb(java.lang.String dbName)
Restore default read behavior when using synchronous database replication.

Parameters:
dbName - the name of the VERSANT database which is used in setPreferredDb.

setFlushObjects

public void setFlushObjects(HandleVector objects,
                            int options)
Sets the objects to be flushed and options controlling the flushing behavior.

This method is for use with XA only. See also the chapter "XA JVI."

The options parameter controls the flushing behavior. The following options are supported:

  • Constants.FLUSH_RETAIN_OBJECT - Retain instance and schema objects in the cache when flushing. The default is to release objects from the cache. If the HandleVector is set to null, all objects are retained; otherwise, only the objects in the vector are retained.
  • Constants.FLUSH_RETAIN_SCHEMA_OBJECT - Retain schema objects in the cache when flushing. The default is to release schema objects from the cache.
  • Constants.FLUSH_CLEAN_CODS - Clean the VERSANT COD table after flushing objects. If the HandleVector is set to null, all objects in the cache will be cleaned from the COD table; otherwise, only the objects in the vector will be cleaned. Cleaning the COD table may be necessary for applications that access a large number of objects.
  • The persistent objects referred to in the HandleVector will be flushed to the database server when either the flush() method is invoked (by the user), or when the XAResource.end(xid) is invoked. If the HandleVector is set to null, then all dirty objects in the cache will be flushed.

After objects are flushed to the database server, the list of objects and the options are reset. It is necessary to invoke setFlushObjects() again to set the list of objects and flushing options.

Overrides:
setFlushObjects in class MSession
Parameters:
objects - The persistent objects to flushed from the database server when either flush() method is invoked (by the user), or when the XAResource.end(xid) is invoked. If this is set to null, all the dirty objects in the cache will be flushed.
options - The flushing options for these objects
See Also:
and setFlushOptions(int)

setFlushOptions

public void setFlushOptions(int options)
Sets the flushing options, and specifies that all objects in the cache are to be flushed.

This method is for use with XA only. See also the chapter "XA JVI."

The options parameter controls the flushing behavior. The following options are supported:

  • Constants.FLUSH_RETAIN_OBJECT - Retain instance and schema objects in the cache when flushing. The default is to release objects from the cache. All objects are retained.
  • Constants.FLUSH_RETAIN_SCHEMA_OBJECT - Retain schema objects in the cache when flushing. The default is to release schema objects from the cache.
  • Constants.FLUSH_CLEAN_CODS - Clean the VERSANT COD table after flushing objects. All objects in the cache will be cleaned from the COD table. Cleaning the COD table may be necessary for applications that access a large number of objects.
    • After objects are flushed to the database server, the list of objects and the options are reset. It is necessary to invoke setFlushObjects() again to set the list of objects and flushing options.

    This method is equivalent to setFlushObjects(null, options).

    Parameters:
    options - The flushing options
    See Also:
    FundSession.flush(), FundSession.setFlushObjects(HandleVector,int)

    flush

    public void flush()
    Flushes objects to the backend immediately, instead of waiting for invocation of XAResource.end(xid). Objects are flushed with the behavior described in setFlushObjects(). After the flush() method is invoked, the list of objects and flushing options specified in setFlushObjects() is reset.

    This method is for use with XA only. See also the chapter "XA JVI."

    Overrides:
    flush in class MSession
    See Also:
    FundSession.setFlushObjects(HandleVector,int), FundSession.setFlushOptions(int)

    setUserLogin

    public void setUserLogin(java.lang.String userName,
                         java.lang.String userPassword)
    Set the user name and the user password. This api can be used after a session is created to change the current user name and password. This api makes it possible to connect to a database with a user name and password that is different from the user name and password used during session creation.

    xa_open

    public void xa_open()
    This method is called by the TM to open the Resource manager. Resource manager initialization is done and the RM is prepared for participating in a distributed transaction environment.

    xa_close

    public void xa_close()
    This method is called by the TM to close the RM.

    xa_start

    public void xa_start(javax.transaction.xa.Xid xid,
                     int flags)
    This method informs the RM to start work on behalf of a transaction branch.

    Parameters:
    xid - The global transaction identifier to be associated with the resource.
    flags - Must be set to TMNOFLAGS, TMJOIN, or TMRESUME.

    xa_end

    public void xa_end(javax.transaction.xa.Xid xid,
                   int flags)
    This method ends the work performed on behalf of a transaction branch. The RM disassociates the XA resource from the transaction branch specified and let the transaction be completed.

    Parameters:
    xid - the global transaction identifier that is the same as what was used previously in the start method.
    flags - Must be set to TMSUCCESS, TMFAIL, or TMSUSPEND.

    xa_prepare

    public int xa_prepare(javax.transaction.xa.Xid xid)
    This method is called to request a RM to prepare for a transaction commit of the transaction specified by xid. All associations for xid must have been ended by using end with the TMSUCCESS flag.

    Parameters:
    xid - The global transaction identifier.

    xa_commit

    public void xa_commit(javax.transaction.xa.Xid xid,
                      int flags)
    This method is called to commit the global transaction specified by xid. All associations for xid must have been ended with the TMSUCCESS flag.

    Parameters:
    xid - The global transaction identifier.
    flags - To indicate the RM should use a one-phase commit protocol use TMONEPHASE otherwise set the flags to TMNOFLAGS

    xa_rollback

    public void xa_rollback(javax.transaction.xa.Xid xid)
    This method informs the RM to roll back work done on behalf of the transaction branch.

    Parameters:
    xid - The global transaction identifier.

    xa_recover

    public javax.transaction.xa.Xid[] xa_recover(int flags)
    This method is called to obtain a list of prepared transaction branches from the RM. The TM calls this method during recovery to obtain the list of transaction branches that are currently in prepared states. This method may be invoked one or more times during a recovery scan. The RM maintains a cursor which marks the current position of the prepared transaction list. Each invocation of the recover method moves the cursor passed the set of xids that are returned.

    Parameters:
    flags - Must be set to either TMSTARTSCAN, TMENDSCAN, or TMNOFLAG. It indicates where the recover scan should start or end, or start and end.

    xa_forget

    public void xa_forget(javax.transaction.xa.Xid xid)
    This method is called to tell the RM to forget about a transaction branch.

    Parameters:
    xid - The global transaction identifier to be forgotten.

    getCodCount

    public int getCodCount(int state)
    Returns the count of cached object descriptors specified by parameter state.

    Parameters:
    state - Valid input states are:
    • Constants.COD_ITER_ALL : Count of all CODs
    • Constants.COD_ITER_CACHED : Count of CODs for cached objects
    • Constants.COD_ITER_DIRTY : Count of CODs for dirty objects
    • Constants.COD_ITER_DELETED : Count of CODs for deleted objects
